script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good morning! I'm Dr. Martinez. What brings you in today?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Hi, my daughter Emma has been complaining about her tummy hurting since last night. She's been really fussy and not eating much.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm sorry to hear Emma isn't feeling well. Can you tell me more about when the pain started?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: It started around bedtime yesterday. She was playing normally all day, then suddenly said her tummy hurt and started crying.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi Emma! Can you show me where your tummy hurts?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Here... it hurts here!

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I see you're pointing to your belly button area. Has she had any vomiting or diarrhea?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No vomiting, but she did have one loose stool this morning. Not her usual. And she barely touched her breakfast.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any fever? Have you taken her temperature?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I checked this morning - it was 99.8. Not too high, but definitely warmer than normal.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Emma, I'm going to feel your tummy very gently, okay? Tell me if it hurts.

script.speaker: child
script.text: No! Don't touch!

script.speaker: parent
script.text: It's okay sweetie, the doctor needs to check. She's been very protective of her stomach.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I understand Emma. I'll be very, very gentle. Can you take some deep breaths with me?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I can feel some tenderness in the right lower area, and there's some guarding. Has she had any recent illnesses?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She had a cold about two weeks ago, but that cleared up. No other illnesses recently.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any family history of abdominal problems or inflammatory bowel conditions?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Not that I know of. My husband had his appendix out when he was a teenager, but that's about it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Emma, can you walk around the room for me? I want to see how you move.

script.speaker: child
script.text: It hurts when I walk!

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I can see she's favoring her right side and walking bent over slightly. This is concerning for possible appendicitis.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Appendicitis? But she's only two! Isn't that too young?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: While less common in toddlers, it can happen. The combination of right lower quadrant pain, low fever, and guarding are concerning signs.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'd like to get some blood work and possibly an ultrasound to help us determine what's going on.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Should I be worried? What do we do next?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I want to be thorough and rule out appendicitis. We'll get the tests done quickly, and I'll have surgery consulted as well.

script.speaker: child
script.text: I want to go home!

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I know sweetie. How long will the tests take?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: The blood work will be about 30 minutes, ultrasound shortly after. I'll make sure you're both comfortable while we wait.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay, let's get started then. Whatever Emma needs.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Perfect. The nurse will be right in to get that blood draw, and I'll check back with you soon.
